data.title: A walk to the capital
data.text: Nothing great! I didn't feel too safe walking in that area of town. Lots of homeless folks. Most of the courthouses and administration buildings in the area. Very busy part of town during the week.

data.title: Full of History
data.text: Beautiful area and well marked with history signs everywhere with good information. We went on a sunday afternoon and it wasn't busy.

data.title: One of the most interesting State Capitol buildings I've seen
data.text: If visiting different state capitol buildings is your thing, this will be right up your alley.  What a fantastic historical building.  Just amazing.  The 24-carat gold dome is spectacular.  I was very lucky to be there on a perfectly clear day.  Just gorgeous!  What an incredible place to visit.  And even better, I was there on a weekend, so there were very few people strolling around the grounds.  I had the Capitol all to myself.  The building is a very special place and you certainly feel this when visiting.  Don't forget to stop by the honorary garden / area dedicated to President Jimmy Carter.  It's amazing to see all of the different titles, both political and personal that he holds.  The Georgia State Capitol is a truly special place to visit when in Atlanta.

data.title: Great historical place with interesting texts in the signs around the building
data.text: Great historical place with interesting texts in the signs around the building: most of them are from a century ago and they provide a different view from today´s version of History. Free and interesting to see the polititians walking around.

data.title: Interesting Building and history
data.text: Well worth a visit, there is a very good museum on the top floor which includes political and other history of Georgia. It was particularly interesting to read about the historic (and not so historic) corruption and graft. The politicians were not in session but you could access the chambers. No charge and it is a self-guided tour (unless you can organise a group).

data.title: Beautiful building
data.text: The wecurity guard was polite,,friendly, and nice.  We took a quick tour of the first floor.  The cuppola is beautiful.  We only spent about 30 minutes there.  You could definitely take more time...around 1.5 hours.

data.title: Magnificent building
data.text: It is a beautiful building. It is a shame it is wasted on politics and politicians. Seems like we should reserve this building for school children and put the politicians in their schools for some very needful education. Seems like a much better use of the space.

data.title: Disappointing Visit and Not Well Shown
data.text:
Things which may be helpful: 1) Atlanta traffic is famous for a reason, and parking is a problem once you get to the Capitol; 2) There are a couple of public lots for a flat fee of $10 near the building; 3) The website talks about tours at 11:00 but we found out that they only operate tours for groups of 10+; 4) You can walk throughout the building once you pass through security but the self-guided information is not very helpful; 5) The "museum" is mostly in the corridors and we found the material not well presented.

We stop at state capitols whenever we can.  This building is not relatively impressive, and the lack of a tour made it hard to understand the history of the building or key milestones of the State.  If you can get on a tour they run about 40 minutes.  Also, the day we were there neither chamber was in session and, for some reason, they lock the doors so we couldn't even see the space.  We saw as much as we could and it took a total of about 1.5 hours inside and outside.

Out of the 20 capitols we have seen we would rate this one average, at best.  There is a lot to do in Atlanta so you will have to decide if this is worth the effort and time.

If this review is helpful then please indicate so below.

data.title: check another off the list.
data.text: being a Texan, we are proud of our state capitol building, the folks of Georgia should be proud also.  This is a beautiful building, with wonderful grounds.  Glad I stopped in to see it.

data.title: Nice Capitol. Free tours.
data.text: Beautiful building - free tours of about 40 minutes. Tour guide was interesting. Interesting small but elaborate museum on 3rd floor where you can easily spend another 30 minutes. About 1 mile from Centennial Park

data.title: Hard to find parking. A lot of homeless in the area.
data.text: We visit the capitols whenever we can. It's a decent looking building with a lot of interesting history. The bummers: trying to find parking; and the large homeless population around the area. It's always a unique experience to visit the capitols. Some are definitely better than others. This one was just okay. But, if you are like us - we visit to try and catch any politicians actually "working". So far - they have always been out of session. So disappointing. It's worth a stop if you are interested in architecture and the stories behind it all.

data.title: The state capital
data.text: I enjoyed walking around the Capital because each floor has a lot of history and artifacts along wish statues and exhibits about the history of the state capital from the year it was built and open for.  Business.

data.title: its a shame these people claim to lead us
data.text: It was a waste for time parking was a about imposible we got watch these people wasting their limted time passing resolution patting each other on the back

data.title: Nice tour of ineresting building
data.text:
We try to hit the capitol building whenever we visit a state capital on our travels. Atlanta's capitol building a little more difficult to visit, parking was not obvious, nor was the entrance. We saw people going in the side, we did too. It turned out to be an employee entrance. The guard had no knowledge of an available tour, he handed us a brochure and said to look around. We bumped into a guide on the fourth floor and she showed us around. 
The building is very nice, but not extravagant as say Texas or Pennsylvania. Enjoy your tour, it starts at the front door.

data.title: Want a dose of reality, go sit in on a session one morning...
data.text: I was absolutely shocked when sitting in on a session, that in 2016, we still read from the Bible before a government assembly....but then again, this is Georgia.  The vast majority of the representatives are older white men, and looking down form the balcony, it was clear to me that THE PEOPLE are not at all truly represented in this chamber.

data.title: Impressive
data.text: not far from underground Atlanta is the state capital it was not in session so very quiet.  A few vending machines in the basement

data.title: Go when the House and Senate are in Session
data.text: I took a group of seniors in January and we were able to visit the museum, sit in on a session of the House of Representatives, and a session of the Senate.  No large bags and you need permission to slip into the visitors gallery in both areas.  I rode MARTA to the Georgia State station and walked 2-3 blocks to the Capitol.  There is a great food court in the same building as the MARTA station.

data.title: The Capitol's glistening dome adds character to the Atlanta skyline
data.text: The Georgia State Capitol compares quite favorably with the dozens of other capitols I've seen. The thing that impresses me most about it is the structure's golden dome. Atlanta's downtown skyline is pretty much like that of any other big city of the New South, being dominated by a rather nondescript collection of high rises. However, the glistening dome of the capitol lends distinctive character to the city's skyline. The many photos contributed by  other reviewers confirm that this building looks impressive closeup. I've added one showing that a person can easily see the capitol dome when  traveling on the downtown connector from the airport (ATL, Hartsfield).

data.title: Serene. But homeless people scattered everywhere.
data.text: Nice building. I took some good pictures. But the sidewalk in that area isn't clean. You'll come across homeless people there. Just the signs of government not at its best.

data.title: Well worth a visit.
data.text: The capitol building is absolutely lovely and the museum is very informative.  Go in to the office on the ground floor to sign the register.  The people working there and the front reception security are very nice and helpful.
